questions.question: A 50-year-old woman underwent a screening colonoscopy. A single polyp is found, resected,and sent for histopathological examination. Which of the following biopsy findings will havethe highest risk of malignancy?
During a colonoscopy on a 58-year-old female patient, a smooth nodular polyp is found andexcised. The microscopic image is given. Choose the incorrect statement regarding the polyp.

options.C: Usually seen in the 6th and 7th decade of life
options.D: Malignant transformation takes place within 5 years.563

questions.explanation: Hyperplastic polyps, as seen in the histological picture, do not have malignant potential.Elongated crypts, i.e., serrated (saw-toothed) or star-shaped appearance, is a characteristic featureof a hyperplastic polyp.They are the most common type of colorectal polyps and are usually seen in the 6th and 7thdecade of life. More than 90% occur in rectosigmoid region.

questions.question: The biopsy of a polyp reported dysplasia up to the colonic submucosa. Classify this lesionusing Haggitt's classification:
questions.explanation: According to Haggitt's classification, a polyp invading the submucosa comes under level 4.

questions.question: A 35-year-old patient undergoes a screening colonoscopy after his brother was diagnosed withcolorectal cancer. Which of the following, if detected, does not indicate a risk of developingcolon cancer?

options.A: Villous adenomas in the ascending colon
options.B: More than 100 polyps in the transverse and descending colon
options.C: Inflammatory polyps in the sigmoid colon and rectum
options.D: Sessile serrated adenomatous polyps in the sigmoid colon

questions.explanation: Inflammatory polyps are not premalignant.576Inflammatory polyps (pseudopolyps) are found in cases of:• Inflammatory bowel disease (most common)• Amebic colitis• Ischemic colitis•Schistosomal colitisMicroscopic examination shows islands of normal, regenerating mucosa (the polyp) surroundedby areas of mucosal loss.lumenulcerpseudopolypmuscularismucosasubmucosamuscularis externa(propria)

questions.question: A 12-year-old is brought to the emergency with features of intestinal obstruction. Anultrasound reveals a target sign, suggesting intussusception. On closer examination, her palmand oral mucosa are spotted with multiple 1-2 mm blue-gray macules. What is the most likelydiagnosis?564
questions.explanation: The patient most likely has Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.It is characterized by hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract (more commonly smallintestine) and hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits. In the given clinicalscenario, the patient has had an intestinal intussusception. The numerous polyps in Peutz-Jegherssyndrome often serve as a lead point.Option A: Turcot syndrome constitutes colorectal polyps and brain tumors (including cerebellarmedulloblastoma and glioblastomas)Option B: Lynch syndrome is also called hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC). It is dueto defective mismatch repair (MMR) of DNA.Option D: Cowden syndrome is characterized by polyps of the stomach or colon, macrocephalyand benign tumors of thyroid, breast, and uterus.

questions.question: Ophthalmoscopy performed on a 14-year-old boy had the given incidental finding. Familyhistory revealed that his grandfather had colon cancer and an aunt was diagnosed withendometrial carcinoma. Genetic testing confirmed APC gene mutation. Which of thefollowing is false about his condition?565

options.A: Condition can be passed on to his daughter in the future
options.B: Mutation of APC gene is on chromosome 15

questions.explanation: 577The given image showing a pigmented retina, the patient's family history and APC gene mutationis suggestive of familial adenomatous polyposis. Familial adenomatous polyposis is due tothe mutation of APC gene located on the long arm of chromosome 5 (5q21), not 15.Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is autosomal dominant. It is characterized by the presenceof >100 adenomatous polyps in colon and rectum. It usually manifests by the late 2nd or early3rd decade. Although it accounts for 1% of all colorectal carcinoma, the risk of development ofcancer is 100%.CHRPE (Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epthelium) is the earliest extra-colonicmanifestation of FAP, present in up to 75% of patients.

questions.question: All of the following are gastrointestinal manifestations seen in patients with FAP except:

options.B: Fundal gland hyperplasia in gastric polyp

questions.explanation: Esophageal carcinoma is not associated with FAPFamilial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is associated with gastric and duodenal polyps inapproximately 50% of the affected individuals.Most of the gastric polyps represent fundic gland hyperplasia and have limited malignantpotential. Duodenal polyps are adenomatous in nature and premalignant.Patients with FAP have an increased risk for duodenal ampullary cancer.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a component of Gardner's syndrome?
questions.explanation: Gardner's syndrome does not include brain tumors.Components of Gardner's syndrome:• Osteomas: most common manifestation, most commonly in the mandible• Polyposis colon•Dental anomalies (supernumerary tooth, absent tooth, impacted tooth).Epidermal inclusion cysts•Desmoid tumorsNote:Turcot's syndrome includes brain tumor and colorectal polyps.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common presentation of abdominal desmoid tumor?
questions.explanation: Explanation:The most common presentation of an abdominal desmoid tumor is an abdominal mass.578Desmoid tumors, also known as fibromatosis, aggressive fibromatosis or desmoid-typefibromatosis are locally aggressive tumors that lack metastatic potential. Desmoid tumors can besporadic in origin or associated with familial adenomatous polyposis.These tumors arise from fibro-aponeurotic tissue and typically are manifested as a slowly growingmass. They present as firm, non-painful, non-tender masses in the abdominal wall, shoulder, hipand limbs, mesentery, and pelvis. They are also associated with trauma, pregnancy, and oralcontraceptive usage.The investigation of choice for a desmoid tumor is MRI. It is superior to CT in defining thepattern and the extent of involvement and can determine recurrence after surgery. Diagnosis isestablished by a biopsy with immunohistochemistry, which stains positive for beta-catenin, actinand vimentin, and negative for desmin, cytokeratin and S-100.Treatment:• An initial observation is preferred for stable, asymptomatic, primary or recurrent desmoids,especially if surgery can cause high mortality.• Surgical resection with negative margin clearance is reserved for patients with small abdominalwall tumors associated with pain or an increase in size.•Tamoxifen and NSAIDs are used as first-line medical therapy. Other systemic treatment optionsare low-dose chemotherapy, tyrosinase kinase inhibitors, and full-dose chemotherapy• Radiotherapy is preferred for candidates unfit for surgery, patients refusing surgery and whensurgical resection is associated with high morbidity.

questions.question: A 29-year-old man was brought to the hospital with a history of headache and vomiting forthe past 7 days and an episode of a tonic-clonic seizure. The image of the MRI scan is shownbelow. Colonoscopy revealed numerous polyps in the colon and the rectum which were found566to be adenomatous on biopsy. What is the most likely diagnosis?bG2350.02501:293553ONOSEA HEP NE21/90
questions.explanation: In the given clinical scenario, the patient has numerous adenomatous polyps and a tumor in thebrain. Therefore the most likely diagnosis is Turcot's syndrome. It is a variant of familialadenomatous polyposis.Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant condition and is caused due tothe mutation in the APC gene located on chromosome 5.Clinically, patients develop hundreds to thousands of adenomatous polyps in the colon andrectum. Some patients may also develop duodenal adenomas. The lifetime risk of developingcolorectal carcinoma in these patients is 100%.The treatment of the FAP includes total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis(IPAA).Variants of FAP are:•Gardner's syndrome- It is an autosomal dominant variant of FAP. In addition to colonic polypsthe patients will have• Osteomas of the mandible or skull•Epidermal cysts• Soft tissue tumors like desmoid tumor579• Turcot's syndrome- In addition to the colonic polyps the patients will have central nervoussystem tumors (primary brain tumors).Option D: Peutz-Jegher's syndrome is not related to familial adenomatous polyposis. It is anautosomal dominant disease characterized by• Pigmentation of the mouth and lips.•Multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small and large intestine.

questions.question: Colonoscopy and biopsy on a 35-year-old man revealed hundreds of adenomatous polyps inthe entire descending and sigmoid colon. Options for prophylactic surgery are discussed.Which of the following procedures will reduce the occurrence of malignancy the most?

options.B: Total colectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis
options.C: Total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis

questions.explanation: The clinical scenario is diagnostic of familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome. To prevent anoccurrence of cancer, total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis is the managementof choice. This procedure is usually accompanied by resection of the rectal mucosa.Following surgery, the patient has to be routinely followed up for ileoanal-pouch surveillance.Upper GI endoscopy should also be performed to evaluate for the presence of duodenaladenomas.

questions.question: A 40-year-old man was recently diagnosed and treated for an autosomal dominant disorder.The gross specimen of his resected colon is given in the image. What is the initial step inscreening his 9-year-old child?567

options.A: Genetic testing for APC gene mutation
options.B: Genetic testing for MSH-6 gene mutation
options.C: Routine flexible sigmoidoscopy starting from 10 years of age
options.D: Routine colonoscopy starting from 10 years of age

questions.explanation: More than 100 colonic polyps are diagnostic of familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome andthe initial step in screening the child syndrome is to perform genetic testing for APC genemutation.If screening is positive, flexible sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy is done annually starting from 10years of age.If the APC testing is negative, then the risk of developing colorectal carcinoma in the relative issimilar to the general population. The screening can be started from 50 years of age.

questions.question: Which among the following is true about Amsterdam criteria?

options.B: At least 2 or more first-degree relatives affected
options.C: At least one case diagnosed before 50 years of age

questions.explanation: According to the Amsterdam criteria for hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), atleast one case should be diagnosed before 50 years of age.Option A: According to the Amsterdam criteria for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC, at least 2(not 3) successive generations should be affected.Option B: According to the Amsterdam criteria for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC, at least3 relatives (not 2) with at least one being first-degree relatives should be affected.

Excisional biopsy findings are suggestive of multiple small sebaceous adenomas.Detailed family history reveals that his grandfather and brother have colon cancer while hisaunt was diagnosed with rectal cancer. Which syndrome should be suspected?
questions.explanation: Multiple cutaneous sebaceous adenomas and a family history of various cancers are seen inMuir-Torre syndrome.Muir-Torre variant of hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) may have:• Sebaceous adenomas• Keratoacanthomas• Sebaceous epitheliomas• Basal cell epitheliomas

questions.question: Which criteria is used to select patients for microsatellite instability (MSI) testing?
questions.explanation: Bethesda criteria is used to select patients for microsatellite instability testing.Microsatellites are regions of repeated DNA that change in length (show instability) whenmismatch repair is not functioning. Defects in mismatch repair genes (as in Lynchsyndrome/HNPCC) leads to microsatellite instability.Amsterdam criteria is used for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC in a family. Because theAmsterdam criteria do not include some patients with known germline MMR gene mutations,another set of guidelines, known as the Bethesda guidelines, was established to help decidewhether or not a patient should undergo further molecular testing to rule out HNPCC.

questions.question: In which part of the colon does colorectal carcinoma most commonly develop?
questions.explanation: 582In the colon, colorectal carcinoma most commonly develops in the sigmoid colon.Overall, the most common site of colorectal carcinoma is the rectum.The sites of development of colorectal carcinoma in order of frequency are:••RectumSigmoid colon• Caecum• Transverse colon• Ascending colon•Descending colon• Splenic flexure•Hepatic flexureHepaticflexure 2%Ascendingcolon 5%Caecum12%Transverse colon 5.5%-Splenicflexure 3%Appendix 0.5%RR-Descendingcolon 4%-Sigmoidcolon 21%Anus 2%-OMARROWRectum38%

questions.question: Which of the following are risk factors for colon carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Ulcerative colitis, familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), cholecystectomy, ureterosigmoidostomy,and smoking are risk factors for colon cancer.

questions.question: Which of the following dietary recommendation puts patients at risk of developing coloncancer?
questions.explanation: High-calorie, low-fiber, and high-animal-fat diet as well as alcohol consumption increase the riskof colon cancer.Calcium, selenium, vitamins A, C, and E, carotenoids, and plant phenols are protective.583

questions.question: Which of the following colonoscopic findings has the highest risk of developing colorectalcancer?
questions.explanation: Sessile/flat polyps are at a higher risk of malignancy compared to pedunculated polyps. Multiplepolyps increase the risk of malignancy.The probability of development of malignancy of a polyp depends on the following:• Gross appearance of lesion: Sessile polyps are at higher risk for malignancy than pedunculatedtumors.• Histology: Villous > Tubulovillous > tubular• Size: Polyps of size >2 cm are at higher risk.

questions.question: Mutations in which gene is responsible for malignant changes in late colonic adenomas?
questions.explanation: p53 mutation is responsible for the transformation of late adenoma to carcinoma.The earliest mutations in the adenoma-carcinoma sequence occur in the APC gene and the earliestphenotypic change is known as aberrant crypt formation.The most consistent genetic aberrations within these cells abnormally result in the formation ofshort proteins known as APC truncations. They occur in the mutational cluster region of the gene,an area responsible for ẞ-catenin binding.

questions.question: A 61-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue and shortness of breath. He hasconjunctival pallor and has lost significant weight over 3 months. A CBC reveals lowhaemoglobin and MCV. A stool occult blood test is positive. What is the next best step inevaluation?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario of an elderly patient with sudden onset anemia always warrants screening forcolorectal cancer, as cancers in the right colon often manifest as melena and fatigue associatedwith anemia. Thus, the next best investigation is a colonoscopy.Colonoscopy is the investigation of choice & gold standard for establishing the diagnosis ofcolon cancer.It permits biopsy of the tumor to verify the diagnosis while allowing inspection of the entire colonto exclude metachronous polyps or cancers.Colonoscopy is generally performed even after cancer is detected by barium enema, in order toobtain a biopsy specimen and to detect (and remove) small polyps that may have been missed inthe contrast study.

questions.question: A 55-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and constipation. A barium enemareveals an apple core sign. In which part of the colon is such a growth commonly seen?
questions.explanation: Apple core sign on barium enema is suggestive of a constricting type of colon cancer that is morecommon on the left side. Ulcerative type is more common on the right side.Most patients with left-sided colon cancers often present with increasing constipation whilepatients with right-sided colon cancer often present with melena and fatigue associated withanemia.The apple core sign describes a short segment irregular circumferential stricture of the largebowel that has abrupt shouldered margins resembling an apple core.585

questions.question: What is the most common presenting feature in patients with right sided colon cancer?571
questions.explanation: Anemia is the most common presenting feature in patients with right-sided colon cancer.Cancers in the right colon are more often manifested as melena, fatigue associated with anemia,or abdominal pain (if the tumor is advanced).Cancer of the left colon mainly presents with altered bowel habits, usually constipation andintestinal obstruction.

questions.question: Which among the following statements is false about virtual colonoscopy as compared toconventional colonoscopy?

options.A: Virtual colonoscopy is less sensitive for small polyps
options.B: Provids a better image than conventional colonoscopy
options.C: Easier to take tissue biopsy during virtual colonoscopy
options.D: Less time consuming than conventional colonoscopy

questions.explanation: Virtual colonoscopy is a non-invasive technique and is not useful in taking biopsy.

questions.question: What is the most important prognostic factor in patients with colorectal carcinoma?
questions.explanation: The most important determinant of prognosis for colorectal carcinoma is the tumour stage and, inparticular, lymph node status. The T-stage (depth of invasion) is the single most significantpredictor of lymph node spread.586

questions.question: Match the following patients with colon cancer to the procedure that is best suited.
questions.explanation: All of the given procedures may be performed in a patient with colonic cancer presenting withfeatures of left colonic obstruction. The most appropriate answer is 1-B,2-C,3-A.In Hartmann's procedure, the segment of the colon containing the obstructing cancer is resectedand closure of the distal sigmoid or rectum is performed. A colostomy is made. Later, intestinalcontinuity is re-established by the closure of the colostomy and fashioning a colorectalanastomosis.588This procedure is preferred in patients when a resection and primary anastomosis cannot beperformed immediately due to complications such as inflammation of the bowel, perforation, orperitonitis.Resection and primary anastomosis is done in patients who are hemodynamically stable and havepliable, nonedematous, well-vascularized bowel.In this procedure, the segment of the left colon containing the cancer is resected. The remainingcolon is cleaned with saline lavage by inserting a catheter through the appendix or ileum into thececum and irrigating the contents from the colon. Primary anastomosis between the preparedcolon and rectum is fashioned subsequently, without the need for a temporary colostomyStent placement via colonoscope is a temporary measure to obtain time for bowel preparation forprimary anastomosis. A stent that traverses the tumor is placed to relieve the obstruction. It isdone in partial obstruction and is preferred in old and frail patients.

questions.question: A 60-year-old man was rushed to the ER with abdominal pain, obstipation, and alteredmental status for the last 2 days. Physical examination and imaging findings are suggestive ofperforated intestinal obstruction with peritonitis. After stabilization, he is immediately takento the operating room, where a suspicious ascending colon mass is seen. Which of thefollowing is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.explanation: The elderly man with ascending colon mass leading to perforated intestinal obstruction withperitonitis should ideally be treated with right hemicolectomy and ileocolostomy.In case of suspected colorectal cancer presenting with intestinal obstruction the followingsurgeries are done:•Right-sided lesion:• A resection (right hemicolectomy) and anastomosis if the patient is stable• Perforation with substantial contamination or if the patient is unstable: right hemicolectomy +ileocolostomy• Left-sided lesion:• Resection and anastomosis if the patient is stable• Perforation with substantial contamination or if the patient is unstable: Hartmann procedure isdone. Later, intestinal continuity is re-established by the closure of the colostomy and fashioninga colorectal anastomosis.• Where endoscopic and radiological facilities are present an obstructing left-sided lesion can betreated with an expanding metal stent provided bowel perforation is absent.

questions.question: A male patient presented with dull abdominal pain and rectal bleeding. On investigations, hewas diagnosed with colon carcinoma. Which of the following statements is false regarding themanagement of colorectal carcinoma?

options.A: Stage III cancer is treated with surgical resection and chemotherapy
options.B: Stage II cancer with young age is an indication for chemotherapy
options.C: FOLFOX regimen is used for colorectal carcinoma
options.D: Immunotherapy is ineffective in metastatic colorectal carcinoma574

questions.explanation: Immunotherapy is not ineffective in metastatic colorectal cancer. Metastatic or recurrentcolorectal cancers are the indications for immunotherapy.Monoclonal antibodies such as•Bevacizumab (Anti-VEGF),•Cetuximab (anti-EGFR),Panitumumab (anti-EGFR),• Pembrolizumab (anti-PDL1),• Nivolumab (anti-PDL), etc. are the commonly used immunotherapeutic drugs in colorectalcarcinoma.Option A: Surgical resection is indicated in all the stages of colon carcinoma. Management ofStage III colorectal carcinoma should also include chemotherapy, in addition to surgical resection.The stage-specific therapies are as follows:Option B: Stage II cancer in young patients should be considered for chemotherapy. Treatment ofstage II colon carcinoma is surgical resection of the cancerous mass. Adjuvant chemotherapy isindicated in patients with at least one poor prognostic indicator like:•Young patients•Inadequate lymph node excision(<12 lymph nodes)⚫ Poorly differentiated histology.•Positive margin of resection•T4 lesions• Bowel obstruction or perforation591• Presence of perineural or lymphovascular invasionOption C: FOLFOX is a chemotherapy regimen used for the treatment of colorectal cancer, madeup of the drugs folinic acid, 5-fluorouracil, and oxaliplatin.StageStage I:Stage II:Stage III:ManagementSurgical resectionSurgical resectionAdjuvant chemotherapyinhigh-riskpatients (presence ofpoor prognostic factors)Surgical resectionAdjuvant chemotherapy(folinic acid, 5-fluorouracil, oxaliplatin)Stage IV: Surgical resection with adjuvant chemotherapy RadiotherapyImmunotherapy (monoclonal antibodies) Palliative treatment in extensive metastasis.

questions.question: Which of the following is a false statement regarding different types of artificial stoma?

options.A: Output from an ileostomy is liquid in nature
options.B: In Hartmann procedure, a loop colostomy is formed
options.C: Skin excoriation is the most common complication of ileostomy
options.D: Parastomal herniation is more common in Loop colostomy
